attributes.comment:
I oppose the increase of I-485 filing fee with the combination of I-765 + I-131 filing.
It is actually kind of overcharge in the reality because according to the current
USCIS rules, one cannot file for the above forms once the priority date is reached.
With a proper resource allocation for I-485, there won't be much waiting time left
for an applicant once his/her I-485 process starts, out of which his/her previous
status could still be valid for quite a while. So the actual time the applicant need
to benefit from the other two forms is quite short. Therefore the proposal's
estimation on the use of EAD and Advance Parole is probably too high.

Also, this proposal is based on the assumption that USCIS will work under the
pressure of economic penalty if they do not process application prompt. We know
for a government agent, that's never the case. Efficiency is often sacrificed in
name of accuracy. An agent could intentionally delay the processing of some
forms to gain financial advantages; but the most effective way to correct that, as
what USCIS is facing now, is through executive dealines and regulations. I support
adequate financing to get the job done properly, however, these lump-sump kind of
plans, even they were correctly estimated, very often miss their target.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Anonymous
